text: [Music]
hello everyone welcome to this demo
securing kubernetes from cryptojacking
attacks my name is afan I'm A Cloud
Security Solutions engineer at aquinox
in this demo we'll see a cryptojacking
attack and how you can defend against it
using Cube
armor so what's the cryptojacking attack
cryptojacking refers to the unauthorized
way of mining cryptocurrencies using
someone else's resources in a
cryptojacking attack an attacker plants
a malware into someone else's system to
leverage his resources for mining the
cryptocurrencies and what's the impact
of
cryptojacking the whole process of
mining cryptocurrency is very resource
hungry in nature and it require a lot of
CPU and GPU resources and the more
resources you utilize the more Cloud
bills you get so expense is a concern
here and if you are using some on
premise data center the whole process of
mining cryptocurrencies can cause wear
and tier to your physical
servers here are some of the popular
attacks attack methods for cryptojacking
the first one is fishing where an
attacker delivers the malware through an
email the second one is exploiting
existing vulnerabilities on the server
like lock for Shell lock for Shell
allows you to run any arbitrary remote
command onto a server so you can install
a crypt Miner or any other malware
using remote code
execution the third one is supply chain
attacks where you might be using a
compromised npm library that is
malicious in nature and mining for
cryptocurrencies in the background the
fourth one is directly exploiting the
cloud infrastructure where an attacker
exploits the cloud misconfigurations
like excessive permissions for cloud
resources to mine for
cryptocurrencies so moving on to the
cube armor what is Cube armor Cube armor
is a runtime security engine for kuber
and it's an open- Source cncf sandbox
project cubam basically provides runtime
security for kubernetes with
observability you can have observability
throughout your cluster like file
observability process observability and
network observability and cubam also
supports inline mitigation that we'll
talk about in the later slides under the
hood it leverages ebpf and
lsms here is the architecture of cube
armor you can install Cube armor on top
of an ex in CU cluster by using demon
set so you have Cube armor running on
each node and it is leveraging ebpf for
monitoring and LSM for enforcing
security policies and we also have a CLI
tool to interact with the cube armor uh
you can use the CLI tool to get policy
violation alerts uh into your
CLI Cube armor have this amazing feature
of inline
remediation where most of the security
tools use ebpf for observability and if
they detect anything malicious they'll
try to kill the processor we'll try to
stop the container whereas Cube armor
uses lsms Linux security modules to
enforce some zerust security policies so
you block everything and just provide a
white list of what should be accessed
inside your kubernetes cluster so that's
how you can defend against the attack
before they even happen using the inline
mitigation so moving on to the demo here
here I have a kubernetes cluster running
and I have already installed Cube armor
into
it here you can see all of the cube
armor parts are running and if you don't
have Cube armor installed you can just
head over to the cube armor GitHub just
scroll
down and here you should see getting
started section and if you open it up
here you can see all of the instructions
that are required to install the cube
armor so moving to the
demo here we already have CU armor
installed and plus I also have an engine
XP
running I will try to execute inside
this pod
now we'll clear the screen let's go to
the home
directory yeah and now I'll install a
crypt Miner for installing the Crypt
Miner I'll head over to the XM rig click
on the download
button select Linux download and copy
the
link and here we have downloaded the tar
file
now I'll extract
it we have a new
directory let's CD into
it and here we have the XM rig minor and
a config file so what I'll do is uh I
just want to show you the resource
utilization of our pod so I'll do c CTL
top mods
demo yeah and here you can see that the
resource utilization is very minimal now
I'll start the crypto
Miner I give it a couple of
seconds so our crypto Miner is running
now I'll do Cube C top Parts
again and here you can
see the spike in the resource
utilization it is using way more
resources than it was using
earlier so how do we defend against this
kind of attacks I'll stop the crypto
Miner as of
now and I have a CU policy in here let
me open it up in a text editor
in this policy you can see that we are
blocking some actions we are blocking
executions from the temp directory most
of the time an attacker will download a
binary to the temp directory and will
execute it from there and we are also
blocking some popular miners in here
like xmri dero and we are also mining
some of the reconnaissance tools like
Mass scan and
map and package
managers and we are also blocking ntp
date ntp date is important for crypto
miners for time
sync and we are also blocking the
overwriting of system
binaries so I'll just apply this
policy yeah so the policy is
created now I'll do
karlocks and here you can see all of the
Cub armar logs and policy violation
alerts now let's run the minor once
again after applying the
policy here you can see it's saying
permission denied because of our
policy and here on the logs you can also
see we are using BPF
LSM to block the section on this
specific
pod and here is the resource that was
blocked XM rig and all the other details
so that's how you defend against
cryptojacking attacks using Cube armor
if I delete that policy we should be
able to run this minor again so let's do
that yeah the polic is
deleted now you can see that I can run
my minor again
so that's it for the Demo Box thank you
for your time and if you have enjoyed
the demo give us a start at GitHub and
connect on slack to stay up to dat
